references: Brown, L.N. 1967. Ecological distribution of six species of shrews and comparison of sampling methods in the central Rocky Mountains. Journal of Mammalogy, 48(4):617-623.
George, S. B. 1990. Unusual records of shrews in New Mexico. Southwest. Nat. 35:464-465.
Hafner, D.J. and D.W. Stahlecker. 2002. Distribution of Merriam’s shrew (Sorex merriami) and the dwarf shrew (Sorex nanus), and new records for New Mexico. The Southwestern Naturalist, 47(1):134-137.
Bradshaw, G.V.R. 1961. New Arizona locality for the dwarf shrew. Journal of Mammalogy, 42(1):96.
Shellbach, L. 1948. A record of the shrew sorex nanus for Arizona. Journal of Mammalogy, 29(3):295.

Armstrong, D.M, B.H. Banta, and E.J. Pokropus. 1973. Altitudinal distribution of small mammals along a cross-sectional transect through the Arkansas River watershed, Colorado. The Southwestern Naturalist, 17(4):315-326.
Berna, H.J. 1990. Observations on the dwarf shrew (Sorex nanus) in northern Arizona. Great Basin Naturalist 50(2):161-165.
Jones, C.J. 1961. Additional records of shrews in New Mexico. Journal of Mammalogy, 42(3):399.
Thompson, L.S. 1977. Dwarf shrew in north-central Montana. J. Mammal. 58:248-250.
Clothier, R.R. 1957. A Second dwarf shrew from New Mexico. Journal of Mammalogy, 38(2):256.
Rickart, E. A., and L. R. Heaney. 2001. Shrews of the La Sal Mountains, southeastern Utah. Western North American Naturalist 61:103-108.
Durrant, S.D. and M.R. Lee. 1955. Rare shrews from Utah and Wyoming. Journal of Mammalogy, 36(4):560-561.
MacCracken, J. G., D. W. Uresk, and R. M. Hansen. 1985. Habitat used by shrews in southeastern Montana. Northwest Science 59(1):24-27.
Spencer, A. W. and D. Pettus. 1966. Habitat preferences of five sympatric species of long-tailed shrews. Ecology 47: 677-683.
Baker, R.H. and J.S. Findley. 1953. Sorex vagrans first reported from South Dakota. Journal of Mammalogy, 34(3):382.
Findley, J.S. and J. Poorbaugh. 1957. Another dwarf shrew from New Mexico. Journal of Mammalogy, 38(4):513-514.
Hoffman, R.S. and R.D. Taber. 1960. Notes on Sorex in the northern Rocky Mountain alpine zone. Journal of Mammalogy, 41(2):230-234.
Kirkland, G. L., Jr., R. R. Parmenter, and R. E. Skoog. 1997. A five-species assemblage of shrews from the sagebrush-steppe of Wyoming. Journal of Mammalogy 78:83-89.
Mickey, A.B. 1948. A record of the shrew sorex nanus for Wyoming. Journal of Mammalogy, 29(3):294-295.
Phillips, R.S. 1956. Notes on a captive short-tailed shrew. Journal of Mammalogy, 37(4):543.
Hoffmann, R.S., P.L. Wright, and F.E. Newby. 1969. Distribution of some mammals in Montana. I. Mammals other than bats. J. Mammal. 50(3): 579-604.
Koster, W.J. and R.R. Clothier. 1952. The dwarf shrew, Sorex nanus, in New Mexico. Journal of Mammalogy, 33(2):250-251.
Cinq-Mars, R.J., R.S. Hoffman, and J.K. Jones. 1979. New Records Of The Dwarf Shrew (Sorex nanus) In South Dakota. Prairie Naturalist, 2(1): 7-9.
Martin, R. A. 1971. New records of the Dwarf Shrew from South Dakota. Journal of Mammalogy, 52(4):835-836.
habitat_description:
Sorex nanus has been documented in montane, subalpine, and alpine habitats throughout the Rocky Mountains. Habitats of observation include: subalpine parklands dominated by ponderosa pine, aspen, and Englemann spruce (Armstrong et al., 1973); mixed conifer forests of ponderosa pine, juniper, spruce, white fir, douglas-fir, aspen, and gambel oak (Durrant and Lee, 1955; Clothier, 1957; Jones, 1961; Spencer and Pettus, 1966; Armstrong et al., 1973; Berna, 1990; George, 1990; Hafner and Stahlecker, 2002); narrow, wooded canyons with pinyon pine, gambel oak, and cottonwood (Armstrong et al., 1973); open ponderosa pine woodlands with scattered oak and pinyon pine (Armstrong et al., 1973); talus slopes and rockslides (Mickey, 1948; Clothier, 1957; Hoffman and Taber, 1960; Brown, 1967; Hoffman et al., 1969); alpine tundra (Clothier, 1957; Hoffman and Taber, 1960; Brown, 1967); sagebrush-steppe with antelope bitterbrush and serviceberry (MacCracken et al., 1985; Kirkland et al., 1997); montane/subalpine marsh and meadow (Spencer and Pettus, 1966); clearcuts (Spencer and Pettus, 1966); and dry short-grass prairie (Cinq-Mars et al., 1979). The species’ apparent absence from pinyon-juniper woodlands, foothill shrub and grasslands, etc. are perhaps a result of the species’ elusive nature (Brown, 1967; Hoffman and Owen, 1980) rather than its actual absence.

A single decayed S. nanus corpse has been observed in a stubble field in South Dakota; however the taxonomic identification was in doubt (Baker and Findley, 1953; Phillips, 1956), and no additional individuals have been documented in comparable habitat.

Surveys have not detected the species at mid-elevation pinyon-juniper woodlands or shrublands (Armstrong et al., 1973)

The species has been captured at elevations as low as 1676 m in Colorado (Spencer and Pettus, 1966) and 1400 in Montana (Thompson, 1977). Based on the location description by Martin (1971), a an individual in South Dakota has been captured at an elevation near 900 m. The highest elevation at which the species has been observed was in Montana, at over 3300 m (Hoffman and Taber, 1960).

S. nanus tolerates greater distances to water than its congeners. Spencer and Pettus (1966) found dwarf shrew an average of 36 m from water, and Clothier (1957) reported individuals 800 m from water.
